DataElement.preferredName: Prior Or Synchronous Malignant Neoplasm Other Histologic Diagnosis Descriptive Text
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text description of another histology and/or subtype of the prior or synchronous malignancy not previously mentioned or specified.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Prior Or Synchronous Malignant Neoplasm Other Histologic Diagnosis
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order._An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise._Occurring at the same time or rate._A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas._Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned._Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues._The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Earlier in time or order.:An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.:Occurring at the same time or rate.:A tumor composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas (adenocarcinomas or squamous cell carcinomas), Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Concepts.definition: An article used to connect words, phrases, or clauses representing alternatives; used to connect alternative terms for the same thing; used in correlation; used to correct or rephrase what was previously said; otherwise.
Occurring at the same time or rate.

A neoplasm composed of atypical neoplastic, often pleomorphic cells that invade other tissues. Malignant neoplasms often metastasize to distant anatomic sites and may recur after excision. The most common malignant neoplasms are carcinomas, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, leukemias, melanomas, and sarcomas.

Property.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.:Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.:The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Pertaining to the combined microscopic physical features of cells and their surrounding extracellular environment in tissues.

The investigation, analysis and recognition of the presence and nature of disease, condition, or injury from expressed signs and symptoms; also, the scientific determination of any kind; the concise results of such an investigation.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: the process of identifying a disease by the signs and symptoms (NCI Glossary).

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
